title: What percentage of Germany's population will be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 as of 1 June 2022?
preds: "On 5. May 2022, 102 K vaccine doses were administered in Germany. That means, no less than 63.0 M people (75.8 % of the overall population) have now received a basic immunisation. At least 49.4 M people (59.4 %) have received one or two boosters" https://impfdashboard.de/en/
31 days to take it up another 3%   -  don't see that as a possibility, so might as well go all in
I´m sure it will be a lot, but there are many people who cannot get vaccinated due to health concerns/complications, and there are also skeptics everywhere in the world.
As time goes on so will the people being vaccinated but not everyone would get vaccinated because they would feel like covid is dying down so there is no reason for them to get vaccinated.
75% so far, unless there's a new variant or significant increase in cases, the population is not likely to increase current vaccination rate in the next 7 weeks.
General vaccination mandate against SARS-CoV-2 in Germany is said to be dead on arrival.

At current rates, which are likely to slow, even first doses are unlikely to get to 80% by June (though they could squeak past the threshold).  Second doses lag slightly behind first doses, suggesting them reaching 80% very unlikely.

Using the dashboard provided in the question, I compared the figures for Denmark, France, Norway, Austria, Sweden and Germany. There is an interesting behavior in all cases but Denmark: in the last six months, the proportion of people with only one dose constantly decreases. This might seem obvious since most people who got the first dose will get the second one; however, this could also mean that the vaccination rate is slowing for good, probably approaching a ceiling level for the country. I suspect the anomaly for Denmark that happened in Nov 2021 is due to the introduction of a new population: children 5-11 years old (https://abcnews.go.com/Health/wireStory/denmark-officials-reason-give-covid-vaccines-82822229). That boosted the vaccination rate, but then it plateaued in two-months time. All of this to say that I believe the only significant game changer to increase the percentage by 5% or more would be the introduction of a new population. And according to the German site, almost all the people who got the first dose have already gotten the second one, including children 5-11 (https://impfdashboard.de/). Recently the EU commissioned a new type of vaccine that doesn't contain RNA but only proteins (https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/feb/21/germany-hopes-nuvaxovid-protein-based-covid-vaccine-will-sway-sceptics) and it has been proposed that skeptics would opt to get this treatment. So far there are few doses available, and most anti-vaxxers would still not get this jab. On top of that, it will probably take time to distribute the new doses and it will take at least a month for new patients to get full immunization. Since this question ends in around ten weeks, I'm betting on the percentage not surpassing 80%. If I'm wrong, I think we could see a rising number of newly vaccinated people at least a month before the question will end.

I don't expect another major push for vaccines before the first of June. Especially as summer is approaching and the conversations around COVID are decreasing (even though cases are going up again). It's a new normal.

Up 1.2% in the past month, down from 3% in the month before, up from 2.3% the month before that, around the same as the 2.4% the month before that. So it looks like a slowdown, but if we picked up to the recent peak of 3% today—and held it—we'll hit 80% around the beginning of May. To me, that seems vanishingly unlikely -but I'll keep an eye on it.
Scenarios outside of bin #3 now definitely call to mind the expression: “überaus unwahrscheinlich”! All in.
it is likely that the slowing down of the infection rates and the removal of restrictions lower the vaccination rate, but it is certainly in progression, and already beyond 75% currently.

Rate of new 1st vaccinations now dropping through the 10k/day mark. As the weeks go by and the rates slow to a crawl, the level of “social activation” that would be required to exceed bin #3 seems increasingly implausible. Approximately three months to go and the cumulative fraction of the vaccinated public will grow at < 1% / month of population at current rates.

I think there'll be minimal gains from here on - summer will come and regulations will ease, meaning the people already reluctant to get vaccinated won't have any impetus (and honestly, if you haven't been vaccinated yet you're probably not going to).

It seems that Germany has hit a stubborn upper limit and now that restrictions are likely to ease on March 20th and omicron is doing its thing which isn't that bad then it probably won't increase much more.
Current rate is about 0.5% in 10 days  so need 100 days to make 80%. Problem is that the rate is dropping quickly. 
I want to get to the bottom of a potential reporting issue before I increase <80% more

74.8% are fully vaccinated; 75.0% will be reached soon. 76.0% have received at least one dose, with somewhere between roughly 0.10% and 0.15% being added each week. If 0.15% are added each week, then the number of people who will have received at least one dose by June 1 will be 76.0% + (15 weeks) * 0.15% = 78.3%, and the percent fully vaccinated is by definition less than that. Leaving 2% for some strange thing I can't imagine happening currently.
Major update on closer inspection - the rate does appear to be slowing down.
Looks like the final number will be just shy of 80%

Almost 75% already but progress at declining rate, further stalling in springtime. Some slow progress due to vaccination mandates and people who might take the shot before summer vacations. So around 80% in June is achievable - probably missed by less than a point.

Rate of growth in % vaccinated continues to decline, as expected, and new first vaccinations remain super-depressed vs a few months ago.
Not a lot of credible scenarios out there for why someone who’s resisted this long will suddenly change their mind. The main credible trigger for a potential large uptick in vaccinations at this point would presumably be the emergence of a new, very infectious and deadlier-than-ever variant. Let’s just hope we never see that scenario!

I'm disappointed to say that vaccination rates are not currently high enough to reach 80%. Expected total now reduced by approx 1.2-1.5%. 
Otherwise very similar forecast to 10 days ago https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1388993
Total range 77.2-79.6%: no longer high enough for any confidence in Bin 4.

Doses given are dropping precipitously. 0.2% received a first dose in the past week. 75.8% of the population has received at least one dose as of Feb. 2. I think a very conservative overestimate is that 0.8% will be added to that total in Feb, and I think that rate will continue to drop or stay low throughout the remainder of the forecast period. Then, the total first doses will be at most ~75.8% + 0.8% + 0.4% + 0.4% + 0.4% = ~77.8%. Again, this is probably an overestimate. This is first doses, so the numbers of fully vaccinated won't surpass that. And the number of fully vaccinated is at 74.1% now, so I don't see how that number won't soon exceed 75.0%.  I think the only way that bin 4 could be achieved is with a vaccine mandate, but that process seems like it won't roll out until perhaps fall, if at all. Here's the latest I've seen: "The government is worried that rising COVID-19 infections and the risk of new variants could strain the health system next autumn or winter. It wants to increase vaccination rate significantly by then." "On Wednesday, Germany's lower house of parliament will debate the topic. Details of the bill will be finalised after the debate, and a draft law should be ready for a vote in parliament by March. However, it's not clear if a future bill can muster a majority to pass. Some lawmakers from the Greens and pro-business Free Democrats - the junior coalition partners of Scholz's Social Democrats (SPD) - are opposed to the measure." "The bill could face a legal challenge as it's seen by some as a violation of the constitution's second article, which guarantees citizens' right to self-determination over their own bodies." "The absence of a general registry for vaccination could be another obstacle, as it limits the government's ability to monitor who is vaccinated and who isn't. Setting up a vaccination registry takes a long time and is controversial given Germany's strict privacy and data protection laws, Health Minister Karl Lauterbach said last week." I don't think a mandate is likely to be passed and imposed with a deadline within or near the end of the forecast period. 
https://www.reuters.com/world/us/germany-plans-vaccine-mandate-amid-qualms-over-rights-2022-01-25/  I'm leaving 5% on bin 4 just in case something weird happens, but I don't see any possibility at this point that the total will end up outside bin 3.
Most of the non-vaccinated sofar have been ones that are anti vaccination.
Rate of growth in % vaccinated continues to decline, as expected.

Very little has changed since Dec 1st forecast, except that slightly greater tapering on the second dose uptake could now make the difference between bins 3 and 4. The gradual hardening of anti-vax and vax-hesitant stances, combined with changing landscape as a result of Omicron, now look likely to increase the tapering from 79% at close to perhaps 77.8-78.5%.
All will then depend on uptake of the vaccine for children (adding 1.5-2%), Novavax, and the development of new Omicron-vaccines. 
Now expecting total 79.2-80.5% at close

First doses are slowing down; ~0.35% of the population received a first dose in the past week, and the total for first doses is now at 75.4% (almost 75.5%). At this rate, 1.4% would become fully vaccinated every 4 weeks starting 3 weeks from now. 0.5% became fully vaxxed in the past week. 18w2d=18.3w remain in the forecast. If vaccine uptake remained constant at this level, then approx. 73.4% (total fully vaxxed on Jan 24) + 0.5% * 2 weeks (the next 2 weeks) + 0.4% * 1 week (the week after that) + 0.35% * 15.3 weeks = 73.4% + 6.3% = 79.7% would be the total on June 1. (It could be closer to 80% due to rounding errors.) But I think we can expect vaccine uptake to continue to fall off, especially as Omicron vaccines start to become available this spring. And it doesn't look like a vaccine mandate will be in place by June 1, as negotiations will take time in Parliament; if a vaccine mandate is successful, it is expected to be in place in the fall. So, I'm increasing my forecast further on bin 3.

CHildrens doses have started and are being given 3 to 6 weeks apart. 
if keep up 2% per month then will make 80 I think this is slightly more likely. if we go up by more than 2% each month I will keep increasing. Probably 2.5% this month giving 1/2 % buffer

Vaccine administration rates fell steeply over the last week.
https://ourworldindata.org/covid-vaccinations?country=DEU#how-many-covid-19-vaccine-doses-are-administered-daily
I think it could end up really close to 80%, but seeing this fall, I'm starting to think bin 3 might be most likely after all.
It seems the rate of growth has decreased 16% in the last 5 days compared to the last 2 weeks. The reason for going lower than 80% is due to this decay factor. Otherwise, it's easily over 80%.

Still on track with forecast Dec 1st, but this does depend on the vaccine for children being approved and starting roll out during April.
I'm expecting second doses to gradually start to slow, but still hitting 75% mid-way through February, then getting very close to 77% by end of March. I don't think 85% can be reached due to regional anti-vax contingency and others reacting against any stronger mandating.

Total at 73.0%, with 1.5% added in the past 2 weeks. 75.2% has received at least one dose. If the current rate were to continue, Germany would end up at ~87% by June 1. But that rate will likely decline as cases fall, Omicron vaccines start to become available, and the remaining population increasingly consists of people opposed to the vaccines. Also, any potential vaccine mandate will likely not come into effect in the timeframe of this forecast. Still, I don't rule out the upper bins.
By sometime in early April, we could be in bin 4, or we'll at least have an idea whether bin 3 or 4 is more likely.

Still waiting for Austria vaccine mandate to come in properly (in 2 weeks), but various European nations who are attempting various pushes for vaccinations are still not near the 80% threshold https://ourworldindata.org/covid-vaccinations?country=DEU~AUT~GBR~ITA~FRA

It's gonna be close but my bias that I am actually weighing a little is that some Democratic states in the US haven't even reached 75% fully vaccinated. So for Germany, a whole country, to do the same means you'd have to have huge momentum like seen in the UK to reach past 75%, which is iffy.

Data and vaccination speed from e.g. Saxony is sobering.
Vaccine mandate will arrive later than expected, if ever.
Cities such as Bremen, which claimed to have the highest rate in fully vaccinated adults across Germany,  has the fastest spread in omicron cases recently. This points to two issues: high vaccination rates tend to mull the fully vaccinated share of populations in a false sense of security, which in turn tends to accelerate the spread of highly transmissible variants through risky behavior. Secondly, for the future this could deliver an argument to people skeptic of the value of vaccinations, since the expected high level occurence of breakthrough infections will even out the urge to get first and second shots.
The correct percentage is going to get more difficult to predict, since it largely depends on the final conditions and the effective date of any form of future vaccine mandates and can vary much for supply, seasonal and event driven reasons.
However, it seems the forecast can nevertheless be narrowed down increasingly to the fourth bin, since new first doses are applied at a by and large constant and consistent rate at the moment and the current target rate the government has laid out (including people 5 years and older as far as I  understand) is 80% as a foundation for stopping the spread of SARS-CoV-2 with a pandemic character. The uptake among school children, whose vaccination campaign has started just before Christmas, appears to be quick and promising - logistics currently still seem to be the root cause of delays.

Adjusting my weightings back towards bin #3 because the rate of new first doses delivered seems to have decreased significantly after New Year’s. The continued growth in numbers of fully vaccinated people is now, correspondingly, being driven by a pulse of folks getting their second doses that will soon end. Unless a new wave of 1st doses picks up again, rates will be well on track for bin #3 going forward. We will need to wait a bit longer to see how the political debates and parliamentary voting unfold regarding mandated vaccination in ~Feb-March. New effective incentives are clearly required to achieve bins #4 or 5. I’m leaning towards a higher chance that any new measures won’t be strong enough or rapid enough to avoid a bin #3 outcome in our timeframe. A very nice (German language) visualization of immunization rates over time, as well as break-downs of the immunization progress by age group, state, etc. is here: https://amp.zdf.de/nachrichten/politik/corona-impfung-daten-100.html
Scroll down for the ”Impfungen pro Tag” (= Vaccinations per day) graphic.
“Erstimpfungen” = 1st doses given
“Zweitimpfungen” = 2nd doses given
“Auffrischungen” = boosters given
This link is much more helpful (https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-people-fully-vaccinated-covid?country=~DEU) for visualizing the trend. We are continuing upwards at a pretty steady clip.

Going to revisit my original prediction from my first forecast: As of 24/11 fully vaccinated % is 67.43, there were 191 days to go to June.
So with some major assumptions around timing:
30 days (December) with current uplift @ 0.09 = 2.7
30 days (January) with increased uplift @ 0.12 = 3.6
30 days (February) reversion to current rate @ 0.06 = 1.8
Remaining 101 days below baseline @ 0.02 = 2.02
Total: 10.12
~77% If this was accurate, we'd expect to be at 71.71 as of 12/01.
Actual: 71.68  Surprised at how close this is, but it doesn't tell the whole story as outcome was lumpier than I expected. And it's not necessarily prescient of the next 5 months since I have baked an assumption of decreasing take-up going forward. So I'm going to attempt another extrapolation now. Days remaining: 140 Current fully vaxx rate/day = ~0.11%/day which is approx inline with people who got there first dose pre-xmas. However since then first dose rates have halved. They were raised by roughly a factor of 2 for probably around a month once you take into account the ramp up and dip in the middle [see https://ourworldindata.org/explorers/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2021-10-21..latest&facet=none&pickerSort=asc&pickerMetric=location&Metric=People+vaccinated&Interval=7-day+rolling+average&Relative+to+Population=true&Color+by+test+positivity=false&country=~DEU ]. There was a contraction in second doses over Christmas, but seems to have recovered now. I suspect we have about 2 weeks left at this raised rate. So let's say the rest of Jan goes through at 0.11/day. After that we should drop down to the current first dose rate which is now around 0.05/day. So let's assume that's February taken care of:
- Jan, 19 days @ 0.11 = 2.09
-Feb, 30 (I know it's only 28 days but for the purpose of this lets use a normal month length) @ 0.05 = 1.5 Which takes us to 75.27. So that bin is out by March.  If we assume that rate sustains until the question resolves, that's another 91 days @ 0.05 or 4.55. So even if that is the case it will still resolve into bin 3. I don't think it's likely that rate will be sustained though. I thought that when vaccination was opened to children 5-11 it would increase the rate significantly, it looks like there was an uplift but it's hard to tell if that was because of kids or Omicron. I think the only thing now that will push this over 80 is mandatory vaccination for the general public including children. However I am sceptical that this will happen, especially once Omicron is in decline. I also doubt it will get Germany over 80% before the time limit on this question. For that reason, I'm thinking that my original estimation of roughly 77% is still good, and backing bin 3 heavily again.
Following @belikewater on the basis of attention to the base rate, to the degree possible given the somewhat chaotic history of the pandemic. See https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1368168
We are now at 71%, up from 70.6% nine days ago. So I'l going to shift down a little toward the 75-80 bucket.
Depending whether some mandatory vaccinations are ordered. If omicron runs through as quickly as it has been, and cases are once again low, people will be less likely to see vaccination.

As of January 4th, Germany has slightly less than 71% of its population fully vaccinated. On that very date, it's immediate neighbours have a percentage between 71% (the Netherlands) and 79% (Denmark). Between September 1st and January 4th, there was a rise from 60.3% to 71%. So, almost 10% in 4 months. With monthly percentages of: 64.2%, 66.2%, 68.2%, 70.6%. I think the growth rate will slow down and will not succeed its immediate neighbours.
People not forced by law yet

Looking at a few other countries, (US, France, Austria) it looks like the general trend is that once the latter inflection point (after the high-growth period of vaccination) is hit, the vaccination share generally continues to increase linearly - for at least 100 days in the case of France, about 200 days in the case of the US, and about 175 in the case of Austria. We're already about 150 days post-inflection point with Germany, so our ability to extrapolate is a bit limited. What happens between days 150 and 300? Looking next at countries with higher vaccination rates- this seems also to be the case in Belgium, where the vaccination rate is about 75%. It's not the case in Portugal, where the inflection point happened much later. So here's one theory of the case- the period in the middle section of the S-curve is when everyone who's pretty enthusiastic about getting vaccinated goes out to do it. Then the linear portion post-inflection point is the gradual trickling-in of everyone who is willing to get it but not particularly enthusiastic. That curve will level off as the vaccination effort runs into the die-hard never-vaxxers. So I have two instrumental questions- (1) how many die-hards are there in Germany? and (2) what does linear (or quadratic) growth imply about the vaccination rate on June 1st. (2) first - quadratic growth implies 72% (95% CI 70-74), while linear growth implies 82% (95% CI 81.7-83.4). I think that pretty much runs the gamut, and makes me think that my probability mass should be pretty solidly between 70 and 82, all else being equal. If I take the quadratic growth assumption seriously, then I'm almost certain to be between 70 and 75. Likewise, if I take linear growth seriously, I'm almost certain to be between 80 and 85. Which is more likely? Let's think about (1). Per WaPo (https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2021/12/03/germany-vaccine-mandate-omicron/), more than 71% have already received at least one dose of the vaccine, which to me puts the low end of 70-75 pretty squarely out of the running unless things start to slow a lot. The overall dose delivery rate has started to pick up again there as well. In general, this makes me pretty confident that 8-85 is the right bucket unless things speed up or slow down quite a lot.

Small adjustment to be more in line with the crowd. Later edit: here’s why I have a hard time seeing 85%+ happening in our timeframe:
https://www.cnn.com/2021/12/28/europe/europe-covid-germany-restrictions-intl/index.html

The (new) government had to acknowledge a slowdown for their vaccination target, now aiming at 80% first doses by end of January 2022 (instead of "beginning of 2022"). Considering new vaccine orders (abundant supply) and a protocol that in most cases will hand second dose by week 6, 80% of the (eligible) German population could be fully (as far as the term is defined at the moment) vaccinated by mid-March 2021. There's plenty of time to get things straight with regards to a vaccination mandate, even though Germany's Justice minister appears to be somewhat retarded.
Getting vaccinated will appear to be the lesser evil than footing the pandemic's bill by paying a hefty non-vaccination fee and will thus motivate most eligible individuals without counter-indication to get their jab. Whether or not "more than 85.00%" are attainable, wil critically depend on the Novavax subunit product ("Nuvaxovid") becoming available and recommended by the STIKO ("Staendige Impfkommission") soon in large amounts, and on improvements in vaccination logistics (mass vaccination sites, order management etc) under the newly inaugurated army specialist Carsten Breuer, now responsible for streamlining processes.
https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carsten_Breuer
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kommando_Territoriale_Aufgaben_der_Bundeswehr

Further to rationale on Dec 1st, the recent approval of Nuvaxovid for rollout January ‘22 should help add 1-1.5% to the total, to get just above 80% before approval of vaccination for children expected in March/April.
Nuvaxovid, from Novavax, is a ‘traditional’ type of protein vaccine which should appeal to some of the vaccine hesitant who are uncomfortable with the novel mRNA vaccines. While 55% of of those surveyed said they would be less hesitant of a traditional vaccine, this is untested and I expect only a small % gain, but I still estimate ~78-79% + could be reached without it, making bin 4 more likely to be reached.

sceptisicm and continued protests wont help matters .. besides german according to hoftstede is a masculine country so difficulties in influencing people to change their perception of things is very hard , hence 70 to 75% is my prediction

Current rate => 70-71% by the end of the year, plus a few % more (5-10%?) by the end of the forecast period. 72.8% have had at least one dose.
Vaccinating ages 5-11 may add ~1.5% to 3% in the forecast period.
The incoming Chancellor wants to have a vaccine mandate in place with deadlines in Feb or March, but that may or may not happen. If Parliament passes it, it would likely be applied to age 14+, which is just under 88% of the population. So if a vaccine mandate is passed, it's quite conceivable that >85% (~85% age 14+ + 1.5% to 3% age 5-13) could be fully vaccinated by the end of the forecast period.
Omicron and possibly other variants complicate the situation.
Zeroing out bin 2.

I'm increasingly nervous, with new rules, that I might be undervaluing 80%+; but ultimately very few EU countries have reached that bar even now (including the UK, one of the least vaccine-sceptical countries in Europe - see links below - and who started vaccinating 12+ in September).  But I'll be watching effects of vaccine mandates in Austria... https://www.euronews.com/2020/12/09/which-parts-of-europe-are-likely-to-be-most-hesitant-about-a-covid-19-vaccine
https://graphics.reuters.com/HEALTH-CORONAVIRUS/EU-VACCINES/qmypmrelyvr/

Most countries size of Germany are around 70-80% vaccination. Assuming plateau has been reached, guessing that around 80% by June next year. Future policy changes can affect the this number esp if Germany policies are similar to that of other countries.
Same rationale as Dec 1st, but slightly higher certainty.
Weight on the last bin in case there's a widespread vaccine mandate.

Two weeks since my initial forecast and it looks like the spike in people who are not yet vaccinated coming forward is receding a fair bit. Since my last forecast there have been some major developments:
- Omicron now expected to cause another wave (as observed before, as cases go up, so does the number of people getting vaccines, but only to the point of a case rate plateau - maybe this is due to increased media coverage as a wave grows?)
- Lockdown for the unvaccinated
- Merkel suggesting vaccines may be mandated in the future
- Younger children look to be getting the vaccine offer in the new year (Under twelves make up ~10% of the population) All these are things which are likely to increase the vaccination rate. There doesn't seem to have been anything that would offset this signal in the reverse direction, so I'm going to re-adjust my forecast. Firstly I can't find any data breaking down German vaccination status by age. However I can find Austrian examples and they were recently in a similar place with vaccine numbers https://vaccinetracker.ecdc.europa.eu/public/extensions/COVID-19/vaccine-tracker.html#age-group-tab. Looks like 15-18 age bracker are 60% fully vaccinated, and significantly fewer 10-14's (I am assuming they are not giving the vaccine to under 12's, so that's why that is so low). Esssentially I think the best take-up to be expected by end of spring would be 50%. It seems unlikely it would be mandated for under 12s and I suspect that there will be more hesistance to vaccinate as people get younger. My assumption here at the moment is that about 25% of the 10 million will be vaccinated in the Spring should this come available before March. Secondly the unvaccinated lockdown + vaccine mandates. At the moment there is no mandate and I think they will be reluctant to make one in practice. It certainly doesn't seem to have fed into the first dose numbers over the last week so the threat doesn't seem to be working. I think we will see in the next week or so if the unvaccinated lockdown is having any effect but I'm not sure it will. If you're totally unvaccinated now, and don't really want to get one, then getting your first dose today will mean at least 21 more days before you are able to come out of lockdown. Omicron is a huge question mark but I think there will be diminishing returns in terms of vaccine uptake increasing with cases, as more of the unvaccinated are more strongly opposed to getting the vaccine. All the above considered, I think that a 2.5% addition to my initial base case is needed to account for the under 12's being vaccinated. I'm still skeptical of getting above 80% uptake though.

I'm adjusting because of the growing importance of booster jabs - at present "fully vaccinated" seems to indicate having had 2 jabs, but if this were to shift then we are probably looking at a lower overall rate

The term "fully vaccinated" is ambiguous since we know as a fact that the efficacy of vaccines diminish over time. Therefore "fully vaccinated" will require at least a third booster shot since people with only two doses will not qualify as "fully vaccinated" in June 2022. My answer is based on this reasoning.
If the question would be "What percentage of Germany's population will have received a second shot against COVID-19 as of 1 June 2022?" my answer would be 75-80 %

progress in the tail, means diminishing returns months after month as it climbs.
Last 3 months total progress +5%, till begin June about 6 months to go. 
A continuation of the last 3 month rate means +10%. But in principle the rate should go down and would expect a 6-7% advancement.
The pressures through new variant, regulation, mandate could compensate for the diminishing rate and keep it. 
Hence bucket 3 would cater for range of +[7-10]% vs today (68%). 
Spreading the bucket 2 and 4 around it, bit skewed though.

Germany is already approaching 70% vaccination.  Notwithstanding vaccine-hesitancy by the Ostis and Bavarians, the public will coalesce around science and good government.  Because it’s Germany, because it’s Europe - where Good Government actually means something.
Vaccination rates have clearly accelerated recently, and seem to be staying higher. Fingers crossed that this will last.
Increased upper end slightly due to significant restrictions on unvaccinated people

Slight adjustment. Several have mentioned how many countries are plateauing around +/- 80%, so decreasing the probability of over 85% just a bit. While the vaccination rate has increased in the past days - mostly driven by booster shots, so not helping to increase total % vaccinated.

Cases may have plateaued, but daily deaths are sadly likely to continue increasing until Christmas. My base level for vaccination is 79%+ given this recent surge in cases, which has I think pushed a lot of vaccine-complacent people to recognise the greater risk of remaining un-vaccinated. First dose uptake has doubled over the last 30 days, and I think will keep increasing beyond the peak of the wave due to ongoing public concern, especially now there is also talk of further mandates, another variant, potential regional lockdowns, and even compulsory vaccination on the horizon. For the latter, I expect the proposal to go to debate in Parliament, and perhaps not pass - partly as the motion would not be til February/March by which time we'll either have quite low cases, or an Omicron wave. In either case it is a contentious proposal that may be less effective than positive encouragement at a time when the second dose rate should already be quite high.
https://www.dw.com/en/covid-incoming-chancellor-scholz-wants-vaccine-mandate-in-germany/a-59979157
https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/rise-german-covid-19-infections-flattens-2021-11-30/ Back to doses, and dealing with the Delta wave; I expect the first dose uptake to translate to second doses approx 6 weeks later, continuing the current trend. So recent 1st dose increases will affect totals from the end of December. The increases for October and November are approx 2% each; I'm expecting a peak through December and January upwards of 3.2%/m, before the rate tapers back rapidly. This easily clears 75% during March. But coupled with this we have a new variant and threat of a possible new wave starting in January. The jury may be out on whether Omicron is either more transmissible, more vaccine resistant, or both (and perhaps less virulent) but either way it is clear evidence of the risks a new variant presents. So even if existing vaccines have lower efficacy I think they will still be considered beneficial, while any newer vaccine could easily take 3-4 months to develop:
https://www.cnbc.com/2021/11/30/eu-medical-agency-omicron-vaccine-could-be-approved-in-3-4-months-.html There is also the likely option of vaccine approval for children. As I have commented before I think this is likely to be approved and rollout from late March at the earliest, and perhaps cover 25-40% of that age group within the time frame, dependant on efficacy, which would comprise approx 2-3% of the total population.
Regarding mandating the vaccine, I think encouragement would be less contentious, and they may be attempting this with a recent push for '30M jabs by Christmas' as an unrealistically high bar to see what's possible. In simple terms all the signs point to numbers being pushed a little higher.
https://www.euractiv.com/section/politics/short_news/germanys-next-chancellor-backs-mandatory-vaccination-for-all-from-february-or-march/
Overall I have minimum 79% and a higher range of 84% but allowing +2% for some firmer mandating.

Current rate => 70% by the end of the year, a few % more by the end of the forecast period.
Germany aims to give 30M doses before Christmas => ~80% by the end of the year.
Vaccinating ages 5-11 may add ~1.5% to 3% in the forecast period.
The incoming Chancellor wants to have a vaccine mandate in place with deadlines in Feb or March, but that may or may not happen. If Parliament passes it, it would likely be applied to age 14+, which is just under 88% of the population. So if a vaccine mandate is passed, it's quite conceivable that >85% (~85% age 14+ + 3% to 5% age 5-13) could be fully vaccinated by the end of the forecast period.
Omicron and possibly other variants complicate the situation.
If they're really going to give 30M doses before Christmas, ending up <80% looks very unlikely.

It's not a done deal, but "Germany’s chancellor-to-be Olaf Scholz ‘backs mandatory Covid jabs’"
"Germany’s chancellor-to-be, Olaf Scholz, supports making vaccination against Covid-19 mandatory, German media have reported, as neighbouring Austria is debating how to enforce obligatory jabs from February. Scholz, a Social Democrat, who is expected to be sworn in as Angela Merkel’s successor in the coming week, reportedly told a meeting of regional leaders he was in favour of a cross-party initiative to make vaccines mandatory, as well as requiring customers at non-essential stores to show proof of vaccination or recovery from the virus.“As a delegate I would certainly vote in favour, to make that very clear,” Der Spiegel reported Scholz as saying. The outgoing finance minister proposed a general vaccine mandate coming into effect from the end of February, by which everyone should have had a theoretical chance to receive two doses of vaccine of their own accord."
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/nov/30/austria-pushes-on-with-plan-for-mandatory-covid-vaccines "Germany could make coronavirus vaccines mandatory as early as February or March 2022, according to chancellor-in-waiting Olaf Scholz. But he insisted that the issue would be decided in parliament."
"The country's top officials agreed to boost the vaccination campaign by administering 30 million more vaccines before Christmas, according to Seibert. In order to achieve this, they will include new categories of people who are allowed to administer jabs. This will most likely include pharmacists. However, final conclusions from the meeting won't be published before Thursday, according to the statement."
"According to Reuters news agency, Scholz also supported the idea of introducing so-called 2G rules for customers in retail stores, meaning they must be either vaccinated ("geimpft") or have recovered ("genesen") from COVID-19. The rules would not apply in supermarkets or drugstores."
https://www.dw.com/en/covid-incoming-chancellor-scholz-wants-vaccine-mandate-in-germany/a-59979157 Everyone age 15+ in Germany is 87% of the population. Austria is considering making vaccination required for everyone age 14+, as 14 is the age at which criminal responsibility starts; for Germany, it is also age 14. If Germany mandated vaccines for everyone age 14+, then that mandate would apply to just under 88% of the population, although some exemptions would likely be granted. I don't see why a mandate wouldn't be applied to everyone for whom the vaccines have been showed to be safe and effective, which is expected to be age 1+ by some time early in the new year; school children are required to be vaccinated for everything else, so why not Covid? So, as I see it, a vaccine mandate, if it's applied, would likely apply to somewhere between ~85% and 99% of the population. On the other hand, if Germany's current Delta wave soon comes under control, and there are hints that that's starting to happen now, then there will be less political support for a vaccine mandate. But, again, I think Germany is tired of endless cases, hospitalizations and deaths, with all of the effects those have on society, and they rightfully see vaccination as a way to hugely dampen this cycle. So I think the chance of a vaccine mandate being imposed is fairly high, especially given the incoming Chancellor's position on it. And if a vaccine mandate is imposed, it will likely have a deadline within the forecast period, although Omicron and other potential variants may complicate matters if Delta fades substantially after 1-3 months but Omicron vaccines are not yet widely available. It's not clear whether Omicron vaccines would be widely available in Germany by June 1; they might be widely available a bit after that. But, it should be pointed out that Omicron is so different from Delta that it's fairly likely, imo, that they could co-circulate without one sweeping the other, much like different subtypes of influenza A (H1N1, H3N2). Delta is so contagious, and immunity to it fades so quickly, that if it didn't even evolve (which is impossible; viruses always evolve), it could circulate every year. So even if Delta fades to low levels and Omicron cases rise, I think we should not count Delta out. And I think that consideration makes the application of a vaccine mandate with the current vaccine more likely in the forecast period.  So, with a fair amount of uncertainty, I'd say that a vaccine mandate is fairly likely, and that if one is passed, it would likely be applied with a deadline of somewhere around Feb or March, depending on the political circumstances and currently circulating variants. I think Germany might follow Austria's lead of requiring everyone ages 14+ to be vaccinated, although perhaps they would require vaccinations of children as well, because a) children get infected and can be seriously affected, albeit rarely, b) children spread Covid when infected, and c) children can get long Covid, which can affect them the rest of their lives. (It's somewhat mystifying to me why Austria's mandate won't likely include children under age 14.) So I suspect that with a vaccine mandate, it's very likely that >85% of the population would be fully vaccinated, although it could end up being on the edge between bins 4 and 5, as perhaps up to ~2% of the population might get exemptions. I think Germany will reach ~70% by the end of the year at current rates, and when the vaccines are approved for young children, which is expected early next year, that will add another ~5% of the population to the ranks of the fully vaccinated. If Germany actually gives another 30M vaccine doses before Christmas, that could add another, say, 10M fully vaccinated people, or ~12% of the population, putting the total at ~80% by Christmas. So, in the absence of a vaccine mandate, with young children being vaccinated and an ongoing trickle of everyone else, I think it's very unlikely that Germany will end up <75%. Without a vaccine mandate, I think bin 4 is most likely.
Still, if Omicron takes off and Delta dies down, more people might wait for an Omicron vaccine in the new year.
I worried that Omicron might make a lot of people not want to get the current vaccine, but that doesn't seem to be happening. Revising back up.
vaccine mandates might be coming. austria wants to put people in jail or fine them thousands of euros, who are not vaxxed until somewhere in february. germanys deadline probably would be similar.

As others have noted below, current vax rate + starting vaccinating <12 year olds in Q1 2022 should get them over 75% on its own. Getting above the 80% ceiling seems harder to me; most European countries have levelled out somewhere below that for a while, even France after introducing stricter rules, and I don't see anything right now that suggests Germany will break that trend.  But worth watching rate in Austria over next month or so. https://ourworldindata.org/covid-vaccinations?country=GBR~DEU~ESP~PRT~FRA~AUT

In agreement with many others’ forecasts and rationales, I think that the most likely “base case” scenario involves new vaccinations progressing at approximately current rates all the way through next June, leading to a mid-bin#3 outcome. The expected slow-down in adult vaccinations would probably be offset with increased vaccination of younger Germans who have not been previously eligible in most versions of this scenario.   Although there is a currently intensifying debate on whether to introduce a universal vaccination mandate in Germany, there are some important degrees of freedom here that I don’t yet see much discussion on in previous comments. Particularly, if a mandate were to be introduced, it remains a very open question as to 1) what the timing of enforcement and 2) what the consequences of failing to comply would be. If, for example, a mandate were introduced 2 months from now and people had 6 months to comply, then the mandate would probably be largely irrelevant to the outcome of the question. Similarly, if there were only minor financial penalties for non-compliance—perhaps equivalent to getting a parking ticket—then this too would be unlikely to cause behavior change with the “hard core” 10-20% of folks  who are apparently quite unwilling to receive the vaccine. If a “spot checking” approach to enforcement were implemented, this too would probably significantly reduce the number of reluctant people vaccinated. In short: even a mandate will not necessarily drive numbers up significantly from the base case (bin #3) and bin #5 seems exceptionally ambitious and difficult to see realistically unfold unless drastic changes in public opinion occur somehow. I’m therefore only marginally increasing my probability of bin #4 to represent chances of “mandate-boosted” vaccination outcomes. A few other points impacting my forecast:
The German health care system is functionally quite de-centralized and introducing any mandate would require a new law.  This de-centralization also has lead  to (and continues to cause!) significant bottle necks and logistical challenges in getting the right doses to where they are needed, slowing progress in vaccination counts compared to expectations that some here might have based on an “efficient German” stereotype. The thinking here is: the more vaccines are delayed, the more unvaccinated people get covid and recover, and so the more people won’t see the need to get vaccinated in our timeframe—the German system will recognize these people as having temporary “immunity”, so they won’t be denied access to restaurants, etc.
There seems to be a lot of uncertainty on this, but it seems that a significant fraction of parents who are themselves willing to be vaccinated also seem to be hesitant to vaccinate their own children, and there is much discussion regarding disagreements between parents in the same family in this topic. All in all, there seem to be many possible drivers for a disappointingly small number of Germans to become vaccinated over the question’s timeframe. There seem to be enough Germans and/or German-speakers participating in this Question to justify posting some supporting links from German media and market research. Hoffentlich hilft’s: https://www.marktforschung.de/aktuelles/marktforschung/mehr-covid-19-impfgegner-als-gedacht/ https://www.zdf.de/nachrichten/politik/corona-moegliche-impfpflicht-umsetzbarkeit-100.html https://www.rnd.de/politik/in-mehreren-staedten-und-landkreisen-wird-der-impfstoff-knapp-schuld-ist-die-begrenzung-durch-die-WYZFDQL35SIJVD7STC6W2GCGJQ.html https://www.rheinpfalz.de/politik_artikel,-umfrage-60-prozent-der-eltern-würden-kinder-impfen-_arid,5239896.html

Without Omicron, I'd say chances are that Germany would most likely end up in bin 4, but possibly bin 5 or 3. Reasons detailed here: 
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1356262
But now if Omicron starts spreading in earnest, and it turns out to escape most immunity, as it seems it may, then I wonder what percentage of children age <12 will get vaccinated with the current vaccine once it is likely approved in early 2022. I also wonder whether fewer people age 12+ will get vaccinated with the current vaccine.  If we're going to need new vaccines for Omicron, they likely wouldn't start to be available until mid March, and large quantities might not be available until the middle of 2022. But once they're available, I would expect many currently vaccinated to take them. I believe they wouldn't add to the total for this question. So, I'm lowering my forecast. I also wonder whether the question might be canceled if Omicron does indeed evade existing immunity and vaccination with a new vaccine starts in March.

Germany's under 18 age group is approximately 10% of total population. That means, of eligible (>18 yo) group, 75% of populations are vaccinated (0.67*0.9 = 0.75). Since approval for under 18 was only just introduced, let's assume 0% of under 18 are currently vaccinated, but in the next 6 months 75% of <18 yo also get vaccinated. Therefore add 67% + 7.5% = 74%.
The under 70 age groups vaccination rate is still lower than expected. More vaccine is available but resistance is still high.

ECDCC's current analysis is that vaccination rates need to hit 80% to avoid 'substantial reductions in contacts between people'. It's fair to assume that the German government would adopt 80% as their goal. The German government (as with many other governments) have had trouble effectively legislating in this area, but they still have legal options available.  German COVID cases trended upwards this time last year. The daily infection rate at the beginning of November was 11,000. This number has increased to 80,000 as of 24 November. As the German health system struggles, it's overwhelmingly likely the German government will rely on legislation to boost vaccination rates.

I'm revising my previous assessment for two reasons. 
In my previous assessment I thought about their current rate of  300k jabs per day and halved it as a rough figure for fully vaccinated. What I had not taken into account is that the 300K figure was including booster jabs, so the newly vaccinated rate is lower than what I was originally thinking. 
So. I upped the probability of 75-80% I had also  not taken into account age in the population, though they are vaccinating most ages now. I think some adults may be hesitant to vaccinate children still. So I decreased the odds for 85+% aswell..

At time of writing, 70% of people in Germany are already vaccinated with at least a first dose, so to begin with, I am assuming that those who were already willing to have a first dose will follow up with a second, therefore it is likely they will get to at least 70. so 0% chance of it being below that. 
Another way of looking at it would be that Germany is currently vaccinating about 300K people per day - assuming they were to ONLY do 2nd doses, they would need only 5 days at that pace so that everyone who has received a first dose gets a second. From now until June it's likely they can achieve this.
(I got Germany Vaccination Rates here https://graphics.reuters.com/world-coronavirus-tracker-and-maps/countries-and-territories/germany/ )  So, I think it's a fair bet to say they'll be beyond 70% relatively soon.  For 70-80% bands, i'm being a bit aggressive but again I am confident they will get past 75% based on how they are doing now. I think even past 80 is quite likely, but I still left 3% chance of it sitting between 75% and 80% if there is some slowing of rollout as a consequence of the current surge in cases.  80-85% Has some probability, depending on people's vaccine reluctancy. over 85% I've seen other forecasts putting this quite low,but I looked at support for the AfD party as a proxy for hardcore antivaxxers, and their support is currently sitting around 10%. So I would put an upper bound on vaccination at 90%. If that is the case, it seems reasonable they can slowly reach over 85% by June. There is also some talk about the government putting in a vaccine mandate, so upped the weighting a little bit for that.
Holdout population on vaccines are tricky to convince
If it becomes mandatory, many people will get the vaccination, but there will still be many who refuse.

Max range 77.5-83.5%, but expecting ~79.5% total, depending on timing of vaccines for 5-12yr olds becoming authorised. I'm assuming from April 22 based on:
https://www.dw.com/en/coronavirus-digest-germany-to-offer-vaccines-to-children-in-2022/a-59238911
Currently at 67.5%
Full dose rate increase had tapered to 1.8% /month, but 1st dose uptake has increased 50% in the same period. This is likely to continue until after the peak is passed (transferring to full doses approx 6wks later), before trending back, and continuing lower from 1.8%. (Unless Gov mandates further).
So minimum for next 6 months is 67.5% + increased rate to 2.4%/month tapering to 1.2% = 78%
Maximum includes slower tapering each month + 20% uptake of 5-12 yr olds as ~7% population (+1.5%) = 83.5%
I think it will decided by the timing of the vaccine for this younger group, as it otherwise looks very close to the break point to me.

Realised I made an error reading the current rate of full vaccination /day yesterday so revising my forecast to account for it. Also thought a bit more about the decay in people to vaccinate (excluded by age or hesistancy) as the % vaccinated moves towards 100% Current increase/day fully vaccinated:
~0.06% of the population  At that rate (assuming it continued flatly). Current fully vaccinated % is 67.43, there are 191 days inbetween, that gives an increase of 11.46%, taking us just over 67%. So the base case is that we get 75-80, assuming that rate of increase keeps up.  But that is a big assumption. How long will any 'spike' in people coming forward for vaccination last? From August - September there was a spike in cases in Germany, which is the first such spike to have occured towards the end of the vaccination drive. It coincides with an increase in people receiving their first dose. Cases started rising rapidly in early August and then plateaud at the end of August, and the effect on first doses was that they increased linearly up to that plateau, from 0.09 -> 0.13 (e.g. a factor of 1.4), before falling back to the previous pre-spike plateau and below.  It looks like we are seeing the same increase in first doses again this time around - first doses up to 0.06 from 0.04. No lockdown has been enacted yet, and cases are higher than they were in August, so perhaps there is still some increase to be had in the uplift. However once cases start to plateau, then we can expect the number vaccinated/day to fall below the current pre-spike baseline of 0.04/day. So with some major assumptions around timing:
30 days (December) with current uplift @ 0.09 = 2.7
30 days (January) with increased uplift @ 0.12 = 3.6
30 days (February) reversion to current rate @ 0.06 = 1.8
Remaining 101 days below baseline @ 0.02 = 2.02
Total: 10.12
~77% Things that will influence this and change forecast:
- Cases start to plateau (not necessarily fall)
- First doses start to decrease/day I don't see much chance of going above 80% without a vaccine mandate which I think is unlikely, but I have assigned a small probability to that bucket to account for that.

I think the rate through October of 1.8%/month included some vaccine complacency as well as vaccine hesitancy; at that point Germany had very low case rates and barely over 50 deaths/day. While polarisation will remain, that rate should now go up considerably, at least until a few weeks past the peak. Then I expect the natural tapering to continue, so I’m expecting 2.5%/month+ reducing back to 1.8% and then lower still. 
But added to this is further mandates and lockdowns, as in Bavaria and Saxony, combined with a potential for 5-12yrs doses, which looks likely within 2-3 months given the circumstances, so I’m adding 30-50% uptake for that age group (7% of population), or +2.1-3.5% to the total.
This takes the total just over 80%, or without the additions, comfortably above 75%.

Today, the reported percentage of fully vaccinated Germans is 67.17%. So, my initial forecast will be based on a reference scenario of ~0.046% increase / day (roughly 38k people/day), which has been apparently observed over the past 5 days on average.
Obviously, there are many other social factors to consider such as vaccine hesitancy (particularly in areas like Saxony), or the possibility of more aggressive government mandating (and enforcement!) of vaccination status in the future. These factors are hopefully well accounted for by the subjective and broad uncertainty range that I’m placing around my back-of-the envelope straight-line calculation that would predict ~75.5% full vaccination, if every day until June were like the last 5 days.
Revising upward because the vaccination rate is currently increasing.

1.7% added to the fully vaxxed total in the past 30 days, or about 0.4%/week. They're on the slowing part of the S curve, so I would expect that to be the max rate without expanding the eligible population. On the other hand, Austria has just mandated vaccinations for the entire population: https://www.cnn.com/2021/11/19/europe/austria-national-lockdown-intl/index.html That could also conceivably happen in Germany. 67.7% fully vaccinated as of Nov 17, 2021. 196 days to June 1, 2022. If vaccination continued at the same rate, we could expect 67.7% + 196/30 * 1.7% = 67.7% + 11.1% = 78.8% to be fully vaxxed by June 1. But for the age 12+ population, vaccination will likely speed up slightly during any surge, and likely slow down overall over the forecast period, unless there are vaccine mandates for employment, etc., or nationwide. Barring mandates and without expanding the eligible population, I would expect approx 75% to be fully vaxxed by June 1; any finer analysis requires more work. But will there be a vaccine mandate? Also, while vaccines are currently approved for people age 12+, approval for children under age 12 is anticipated in early 2022. That will add some percentage to the total as well. About 14% of the population is age 0-14, so ~10% is under age 12. If 50% of them become fully vaxxed in the forecast period, that will be 5% of the population.
https://www.bbc.com/news/health-58516207
https://www.dw.com/en/coronavirus-digest-germany-to-offer-vaccines-to-children-in-2022/a-59238911 So, if, say, around 75% of the population were likely to be fully vaxxed by June 1 without expanding the eligible population to age <12, and if expanding it to children adds in the ballpark of 5%, then we're at 80%. Those might be underestimates for both. I really can't picture the total being <75% by June 1. Just under or above 80% is very plausible. More than 85% is plausible with a nationwide vaccine mandate, which I think just became more likely thanks to Austria's actions today.
A first guess. I assume that fully vaccinated will increase between .25% and  .5% weekly. There are 27 weeks left until June 1st 2022.
